segment_text: With a clamor of bells that set the swallows soaring, the Festival of Summer came to the city Omelas, bright-towered by the sea.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: The ringing of the boats in harbor sparkled with flags.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: In the streets between houses with red roofs and painted walls, between old moss-grown gardens and under avenues of trees, past great parks and public buildings, processions moved.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Some were decorous: old people in long stiff robes of mauve and gray, grave master workmen, quiet, merry women carrying their babies and chatting as they walked.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: In other streets the music beat faster, a shimmering of gong and tambourine, and the people went dancing, the procession was a dance.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Children dodged in and out, their high calls rising like the swallows' crossing flights over the music and the singing.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: All the processions wound towards the north side of the city, where on the great water-meadow called the Green Fields boys and girls, naked in the bright air, with mud-stained feet and ankles and long, lithe arms,exercised their restive horses before the race.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: The horses wore no gear at all but a halter without bit. Their manes were braided with streamers of silver, gold, and green.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: They flared their nostrils and pranced and boasted to one another; they were vastly excited, the horse being the only animal who has adopted our ceremonies as his own.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: Far off to the north and west the mountains stood up half encircling Omelas on her bay.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: The air of morning was so clear that the snow still crowning the Eighteen Peaks burned with white-gold fire across the miles of sunlit air, under the dark blue of the sky.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: There was just enough wind to make the banners that marked the racecourse snap and flutter now and then.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: In the silence of the broad green meadows one could hear the music winding throughout the city streets, farther and nearer and ever approaching, a cheerful faint sweetness of the air from time to time trembled and gathered together and broke out into the great joyous clanging of the bells.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: Joyous!
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: How is one to tell about joy? How describe the citizens of Omelas?
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: They were not simple folk, you see, though they were happy.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: But we do not say the words of cheer much any more. All smiles have become archaic.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Given a description such as this one tends to make certain assumptions.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Given a description such as this one tends to look next for the King, mounted on a splendid stallion and surrounded by his noble knights, or perhaps in a golden litter borne by great-muscled slaves.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: But there was no king. They did not use swords, or keep slaves.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: They were not barbarians, I do not know the rules and laws of their society, but I suspect that they were singularly few.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: As they did without monarchy and slavery, so they also got on without the stock exchange, the advertisement, the secret police, and the bomb.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Yet I repeat that these were not simple folk, not dulcet shepherds, noble savages, bland utopians. They were not less complex than us.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: The trouble is that we have a bad habit, encouraged by pedants and sophisticates, of considering happiness as something rather stupid.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Only pain is intellectual, only evil interesting. This is the treason of the artist: a refusal to admit the banality of evil and the terrible boredom of pain.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: If you can't lick 'em, join 'em. If it hurts, repeat it.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: But to praise despair is to condemn delight, to embrace violence is to lose hold of everything else.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: We have almost lost hold; we can no longer describe happy man, nor make any celebration of joy.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: How can I tell you about the people of Omelas?
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: They were not naive and happy children--though their children were, in fact, happy. They were mature, intelligent, passionate adults whose lives were not wretched.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: O miracle! But I wish I could describe it better. I wish I could convince you.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Omelas sounds in my words like a city in a fairy tale, long ago and far away, once upon a time.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Perhaps it would be best if you imagined it as your own fancy bids, assuming it will rise to the occasion, for certainly I cannot suit you all.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: For instance, how about technology? I think that there would be no cars or helicopters in and above the streets; this follows from the fact that the people of Omelas are happy people.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Happiness is based on a just discrimination of what is necessary, what is neither necessary nor destructive, and what is destructive.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: In the middle category, however--that of the unnecessary but undestructive, that of comfort, luxury, exuberance, etc.-- they could perfectly well have central heating, subway trains, washing machines, and all kinds of marvelous devices not yet invented here, floating light-sources, fuelless power, a cure for the common cold.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Or they could have none of that: it doesn't matter. As you like it.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: I incline to think that people from towns up and down the coast have been coming to to Omelas during the last days before the Festival on very fast little trains and double-decked trams, and that the trains station of Omelas is actually the handsomest building in town, though plainer than the magnificent Farmers' Market.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: But even granted trains, I fear that Omelas so far strikes some of you as goody-goody. Smiles, bells, parades, horses, bleh.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: If so, please add an orgy. If an orgy would help, don't hesitate.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Let us not, however, have temples from which issue beautiful nude priests and priestesses already half in ecstasy and ready to copulate with any man or woman, lover or stranger, who desires union with the deep godhead of the blood, although that was my first idea.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: But really it would be better not to have any temples in Omelas--at least, not manned temples. Religion yes, clergy no.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Surely the beautiful nudes can just wander about, offering themselves like divine souffles to the hunger of the needy and the rapture of the flesh.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Let them join the processions. Let tambourines be struck above the copulations, and the gory of desire be proclaimed upon the gongs, and (a not unimportant point) let the offspring of these delightful rituals be beloved and looked after by all.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: One thing I know there is none of in Omelas is guilt.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: But what else should there be? I thought at first there were no drugs, but that is puritanical.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: For those who like it, the faint insistent sweetness of drooz may perfume the ways of the city, drooz which first brings a great lightness and brilliance to the mind and limbs, and then after some hours a dreamy languor, and wonderful visions at last of the very arcane and inmost secrets of the Universe, as well as exciting the pleasure of sex beyond all belief;
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: and it is not habit-forming. For more modest tastes I think there ought to be beer.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: What else, what else belongs in the joyous city? The sense of victory, surely, the celebration of courage.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: But as we did without clergy, let us do without soldiers. The joy built upon successful slaughter is not the right kind of joy; it will not do; it is fearful and it is trivial.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: A boundless and generous contentment, a magnanimous triumph felt not against some outer enemy but in communion with the finest and fairest in the souls of all men everywhere and the splendor of the world's summer:
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: This is what swells the hearts of the people of Omelas, and the victory they celebrate is that of life. I don't think many of them need to take drooz.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Most of the processions have reached the Green Fields by now.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: A marvelous smell of cooking goes forth from the red and blue tents of the provisioners.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: The faces of small children are amiably sticky; in the benign gray beard of a man a couple of crumbs of rich pastry are entangled.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: The youths and girls have mounted their horses and are beginning to group around the starting line of the course.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: An old woman, small, fat, and laughing, is passing out flowers from a basket, and tall young men wear her flowers in their shining hair.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: A child of nine or ten sits at the edge of the crowd alone, playing on a wooden flute.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: People pause to listen, and they smile, but they do not speak to him, for he never ceases playing and never sees them, his dark eyes wholly rapt in the sweet, thing magic of the tune.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: He finishes, and slowly lowers his hands holding the wooden flute.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: As if that little private silence were the signal, all at once a trumpet sounds from the pavilion near the starting line: imperious, melancholy, piercing.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: The horses rear on their slender legs, and some of them neigh in answer.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: Sober-faced, the young riders stroke the horses' necks and soothe them, whispering, "Quiet, quiet, there my beauty, my hope... "
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: They begin to form in rank along the starting line.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: The crowds along the racecourse are like a field of grass and flowers in the wind. The Festival of Summer has begun.
scene_description: outdoors, vast green meadows, distant snow-capped mountains, racecourse banners

segment_text: Do you believe? Do you accept the festival, the city, the joy? No?
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Then let me describe one more thing.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: In a basement under one of the beautiful public buildings of Omelas, or perhaps in the cellar of one of its spacious private homes, there is a room.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: It has one locked door, and no window.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: A little light seeps in dustily between cracks in the boards, secondhand from a cobwebbed window somewhere across the cellar.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: In one corner of the little room a couple of mops, with stiff, clotted, foul-smelling heads, stand near a rusty bucket.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: The floor is dirt, a little damp to the touch, as cellar dirt usually is. The room is about three paces long and two wide: a mere broom closet or disused tool room.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: In the room, a child is sitting. It could be a boy or a girl.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: It looks about six, but actually is nearly ten. It is feeble-minded.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: Perhaps it was born defective, or perhaps it has become imbecile through fear, malnutrition, and neglect.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: It picks its nose and occasionally fumbles vaguely with its toes or genitals, as it sits hunched in the corner farthest from the bucket and the two mops.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: It is afraid of the mops. It finds them horrible.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: It shuts its eyes, but it knows the mops are still standing there; and the door is locked; and nobody will come.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: The door is always locked; and nobody ever comes, except that sometimes--the child has no understanding of time or interval--sometimes the door rattles terribly and opens, and a person, or several people, are there.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: One of them may come in and kick the child to make it stand up. The others never come close, but peer in at it with frightened, disgusted eyes.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: The food bowl and the water jug are hastily filled, the door is locked; the eyes disappear.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: The people at the door never say anything, but the child, who has not always lived in the tool room, and can remember sunlight and its mother's voice, sometimes speaks.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: "I will be good," it says. "Please let me out. I will be good!"
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: They never answer. The child used to scream for help at night, and cry a good deal, but now it only makes a kind of whining, "eh-haa, eh-haa," and it speaks less and less often.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: It is so thin there are no calves to its legs; its belly protrudes; it lives on a half-bowl of corn meal and grease a day.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: It is naked. Its buttocks and thighs are a mass of festered sores, as it sits in its own excrement continually.
scene_description: indoors, dim cellar, dirt floor, locked wooden door

segment_text: They all know it is there, all the people of Omelas. Some of them have come to see it, others are content merely to know it is there.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: They all know that it has to be there.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Some of them understand why, and some do not, but they all understand that their happiness, the beauty of their city, the tenderness of their friendships, the health of their children, the wisdom of their scholars, the skill of their makers, even the abundance of their harvest and the kindly weathers of their skies, depend wholly on this child's abominable misery.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: This is usually explained to children when they are between eight and twelve, whenever they seem capable of understanding; and most of those who come to see the child are young people, though often enough an adult comes, or comes back, to see the child.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: No matter how well the matter has been explained to them, these young spectators are always shocked and sickened at the sight. They feel disgust, which they had thought themselves superior to.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: They feel anger, outrage, impotence, despite all the explanations. They would like to do something for the child.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: But there is nothing they can do. If the child were brought up into the sunlight out of that vile place, if it were cleaned and fed and comforted, that would be a good thing, indeed; but if it were done, in that day and hour all the prosperity and beauty and delight of Omelas would wither and be destroyed.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Those are the terms.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: To exchange all the goodness and grace of every life in Omelas for that single, small improvement: to throw away the happiness of thousands for the chance of happiness of one: that would be to let guilt within the walls indeed.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: The terms are strict and absolute; there may not even be a kind word spoken to the child.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Often the young people go home in tears, or in a tearless rage, when they have seen the child and faced this terrible paradox. They may brood over it for weeks or years.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: But as time goes on they begin to realize that even if the child could be released, it would not get much good of its freedom: a little vague pleasure of warmth and food, no real doubt, but little more.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: It is too degraded and imbecile to know any real joy. It has been afraid too long ever to be free of fear.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Its habits are too uncouth for it to respond to humane treatment. Indeed, after so long it would probably be wretched without walls about it to protect it, and darkness for its eyes, and its own excrement to sit in.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Their tears at the bitter injustice dry when they begin to perceive the terrible justice of reality, and to accept it.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Yet it is their tears and anger, the trying of their generosity and the acceptance of their helplessness, which are perhaps the true source of the splendor of their lives.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Theirs is no vapid, irresponsible happiness. They know that they, like the child, are not free.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: They know compassion. It is the existence of the child, and their knowledge of its existence, that makes possible the nobility of their architecture, the poignancy of their music, the profundity of their science.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: It is because of the child that they are so gentle with children.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: They know that if the wretched one were not there sniveling in the dark, the other one, the flute-player, could make no joyful music as the young riders line up in their beauty for the race in the sunlight of the first morning of summer.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: Now do you believe them? Are they not more credible?
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: But there is one more thing to tell, and this is quite incredible.
scene_description: outdoors, bright city streets, red-roofed houses, festive banners

segment_text: At times one of the adolescent girls or boys who go see the child does not go home to weep or rage, does not, in fact, go home at all.
scene_description: outdoors, ornate city gates, paved road, sunlit farmlands beyond

segment_text: Sometimes also a man or a woman much older falls silent for a day or two, then leaves home.
scene_description: outdoors, ornate city gates, paved road, sunlit farmlands beyond

segment_text: These people go out into the street, and walk down the street alone. They keep walking, and walk straight out of the city of Omelas, through the beautiful gates.
scene_description: outdoors, ornate city gates, paved road, sunlit farmlands beyond

segment_text: They keep walking across the farmlands of Omelas. Each one goes alone, youth or girl, man or woman.
scene_description: outdoors, ornate city gates, paved road, sunlit farmlands beyond

segment_text: Night falls; the traveler must pass down village streets, between the houses with yellow- lit windows, and on out into the darkness of the fields.
scene_description: outdoors, nighttime, dark fields, distant yellow-lit windows, silhouetted mountains

segment_text: Each alone, they go west or north, towards the mountains. They go on.
scene_description: outdoors, nighttime, dark fields, distant yellow-lit windows, silhouetted mountains

segment_text: They leave Omelas, they walk ahead into the darkness, and they do not come back.
scene_description: outdoors, nighttime, dark fields, distant yellow-lit windows, silhouetted mountains

segment_text: The place they go towards is a place even less imaginable to most of us than the city of happiness. I cannot describe it at all.
scene_description: outdoors, nighttime, dark fields, distant yellow-lit windows, silhouetted mountains

segment_text: It is possible that it does not exist. But they seem to know where they are going, the ones who walk away from Omelas.
scene_description: outdoors, nighttime, dark fields, distant yellow-lit windows, silhouetted mountains
